stream_context.summary: Kaze spends most of the stream brainstorming and prototyping visual style for Course 13 (a surreal, gloomy Ice Castle) while also locking down the missing late-game themes. He tests N64 combiner setups live in Blender and the ROM, debates emulator crashes, and juggles chat suggestions about Course 14/15 themes and bosses.

development_findings.summary: Several emulators crash; Project 64 1.6 is currently the least bad option, but even it shows memory-corruption issues in new builds.
development_findings.quote: Right now the game has a lot of issues on a lot of emulators. There isn't much I can do about it.

development_findings.summary: Course 13 will be a ‘gloomy ice castle’ that is primarily platform-focused, avoids puzzles, and relies on suspended icy platforms over an abyss.

Visual direction for Course 13: hexagonal rooms, frozen walls with deep shadows, layered semi-transparent ice textures, blue/black fog for eerie contrast; Kaze experiments with multi-layer combiners and env-mapped decals to achieve depth.
Boss philosophy: boss fights are valuable mainly as cinematic set-pieces; gameplay should not overshadow spectacle.
development_findings.quote: For me, the number one priority when we make a boss is to make sure it's a cool set piece.

development_findings.summary: Leading boss idea for Course 13 is Raphael the Raven: a moonlit cut-scene where a silhouette on the moon jumps down to fight Mario on the tower top; alternative is a giant snowman whose head detaches and attacks.
Level order will be re-arranged to smooth difficulty and control teaching; Course numbers may shift once themes are finalized.
Course 15 must "be a banger" and break at least one previous convention without betraying player promises (e.g., still include retro-pipe).
Rejected mechanics: 30-second day-night cycle deemed ‘anti-fun’ because it forces waiting; heavy puzzle elements also rejected.

Craft-materials world (paper, cardboard, glue, googly eyes, crayons, rulers, confetti, etc.) chosen for Course 14 (or 15) after discarding candy, rainbow-reef, greenhouse, music, and night-day ideas. Will feature paper NPCs with simple dialogue and mostly platforming.
Overworld will be fruit-themed; coins spent on overworld upgrades rather than in-level minigames.

context_findings.summary: Kaze streams every Saturday and prefers constant verbal engagement even though he’s quiet offline.
He dislikes audience ‘back-seating’ and asks for actionable suggestions instead of commands.
Personal anecdote: Zeina accidentally shaved a bald stripe into his hair while cleaning the trimmer.
context_findings.quote: She took the top thing off to clean the razor and she just kept going—huge bald line.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is skeptical of gamer-product sponsorships, calling ‘Gamer Soup’ overpriced instant noodles.
Philosophy: prefers C/assembly and sees language debates (Rust, Zig) as irrelevant—good code is about avoiding bugs, not picking new languages.
context_findings.quote: A language is already not safe if you program bugs. So just don't program bugs.

biobak.summary: Gave color and layout feedback during art tests; suggested spike contrast tweaks and supported craft-materials theme.

zeina.summary: Cut Kaze’s hair; now works from her own office and wasn’t on camera this stream.

key_stories.title: Locking the Final Level Themes
key_stories.summary: The team still lacked clear concepts for Courses 13–15. On stream, Kaze methodically weighed chat and Biobak’s ideas, discarding night-day, candy, and rainbow reefs before settling on Ice Castle for 13 and craft-materials world for 14 (with Space Casino already slated).
key_stories.challenge: Three late-game levels lacked finalized themes, jeopardizing pacing and difficulty planning.
key_stories.process: Live brainstorming, pros/cons analysis, checking overlap with existing levels, and evaluating workload (modeling complexity, color pop, Yoshi relevance).
key_stories.outcome: Course 13 = gloomy Ice Castle; Course 14 = craft-materials world; Course 15 remains Space Casino. Difficulty chart updated accordingly.
key_stories.key_quote: Quest 15 needs to be a banger. We want it to be something that allows for difficulty as well.

key_stories.title: The Moon-Raven Boss Concept
key_stories.summary: Kaze envisions Raphael the Raven silhouetted on a giant moon, then leaping to the castle tower for a cinematic fight.
key_stories.challenge: Need a boss that fits Ice Castle atmosphere and Kaze’s ‘set-piece first’ philosophy.
key_stories.process: Discussed snowman and generic ice spirits, but returned to Yoshi’s Island nostalgia; sketched cut-scene timings and lighting.
key_stories.outcome: Raven concept tentatively chosen; needs technical feasibility check for N64 scale.
key_stories.key_quote: Imagine you are in the castle... you see his eyes slowly open as two glowing white balls coming out of the snow.

key_stories.title: Emulator Headaches
key_stories.summary: Several testers report crashes; Kaze confirms Project 64 inaccuracies and Parallel plugin failures.
key_stories.challenge: Game crashes on multiple emulators, hindering public testing and speed-running.
key_stories.process: Recommends P64 1.6, examines memory-corruption, notes that emulator authors claim ‘accuracy’ yet break hacks.
key_stories.outcome: No fix yet; flagged for future technical pass.
key_stories.key_quote: Hopefully it just fixes itself magically like usual.

open_questions.context: Theme accepted (paper, cardboard, glue, googly eyes, etc.) but layout, boss, and Yoshi tie-in undecided.
